iso_relationship.description: Connecticut is in ISO-NE territory. Eversource is ISO-NE member utility.
iso_relationship.fcm_relationship: Separate from ISO-NE Forward Capacity Market (FCM)
iso_relationship.aggregation_model: Eversource acts as aggregator through DERMS platform
iso_relationship.wholesale_access: Retail program, not direct wholesale market access
iso_relationship.fcm_participation_note: FERC Order 2222 permits restricted dual participation to avoid double compensation

performance_payment.calculation_method: Based on inverter telemetry data during events

winter.note: Estimated based on regional ConnectedSolutions programs

resilience_adder.description: 50% adder for circuits with higher outage frequency/duration
resilience_adder.eligibility: Grid circuits experiencing greater frequency or duration of power outages

commercial_industrial.note: Incentive rates decreased December 4, 2024 for new projects due to overwhelming demand

small.peak_demand_definition: Average of last 12 months' monthly demand (highest 30-min interval each month)

commercial_industrial.tranche_3_announced: Commercial incentives reallocated 140 MW from residential to C&I sector

performance_incentives.payment_timing: Twice per year for 10 years (varies by source)

historical_rates.note: Specific historical rates for CT ConnectedSolutions 2019-2022 not documented in available sources

federal_itc.requirement: Must deduct upfront rebate before calculating ITC

state_incentives.description: ESS upfront + performance incentives can be combined with federal ITC

system_requirements.new_system_only: Systems installed before January 1, 2022 not eligible for upfront incentive

minimum_size.note: No explicit minimum kW or kWh requirement found in program documentation
minimum_size.commercial_flexible: Based on customer peak demand classification

duration_requirements.discharge_capability: Must discharge up to 80% over 3-hour period

inverter_requirements.capabilities: Must support DERMS integration and dispatch commands

approved_equipment.note: Must be approved through New Technology Application process

passive_dispatch.time_window: 5:00 PM - 8:00 PM (3 hours as of Dec 2024)

storm_protection.blackout_period: 2 days before predicted severe outage events

performance_measurement.measurement_basis: Actual battery discharge during event windows

requirements: Battery at same location as electric service account

commercial.size_classification: Based on annual peak demand (< 200 kW, 200-500 kW, > 500 kW)

geographic_coverage.coverage_description: All Eversource and United Illuminating service territories in Connecticut

enrollment_caps.recent_reallocation: 140 MW shifted from residential to C&I (due to C&I demand)
enrollment_caps.enrollment_status: Active for Energy Storage Solutions; ConnectedSolutions closed

application_process.contractor_requirement: Must use eligible contractor from approved list
application_process.timeline_estimate: 3-4 months from application to Permission to Operate
application_process.application_completeness: Complete and accurate applications move faster

eligible_contractors.requirement: Must use contractor from approved list

third_party_ownership.note: Lease and third-party ownership models supported

fcm_participation.fcm_overview: ISO-NE Forward Capacity Market procures capacity 3+ years ahead

2024_fcm_results.note: Significant battery participation in wholesale capacity market

order_2222_implementation.description: DER aggregations can participate in ISO-NE markets

dual_participation.ferc_guidance: Order 2222 permits restrictions to avoid double compensation
dual_participation.principle: DERs receiving retail compensation may have restricted wholesale participation
dual_participation.connecticut_specific: No explicit state-level prohibition found in research
dual_participation.practical_limitation: ESS program uses retail demand response model, separate from FCM
dual_participation.eversource_role: Acts as aggregator through DERMS, not direct wholesale market participation
dual_participation.order_841: Removed barriers to storage in capacity, energy, and ancillary services markets
dual_participation.double_counting: Restrictions designed to prevent same service compensated twice

retail_vs_wholesale.iso_ne_reference: Retail DR operates outside ISO dispatch for wholesale markets
retail_vs_wholesale.aggregation: Eversource/UI aggregate batteries via DERMS for retail grid services
retail_vs_wholesale.fcm_alternative: ESS provides alternative revenue stream to direct FCM participation

stacking_considerations.ess_plus_fcm: Unclear if explicitly allowed; FERC permits restrictions
stacking_considerations.ferc_principle: Service provided only once - no double compensation
stacking_considerations.practical_approach: Batteries typically choose retail (ESS) OR wholesale (FCM) path
stacking_considerations.recommendation: Verify dual participation rules with utility and ISO-NE before assuming stacking

ct_green_bank.role: Administers upfront incentives for ESS program
ct_green_bank.additional_programs: May offer complementary financing or solar incentives

vpp_initiative.comparison: Significantly exceeds ~500 households, 5.8 MW in existing VPPs
vpp_initiative.requirements: Program batteries to discharge June-August weekday afternoons

recent_actions: Approved incentive rate decreases for C&I (December 2024)

connectedsolutions_legacy.reason: Replaced by more comprehensive Energy Storage Solutions program
connectedsolutions_legacy.grandfathering: Existing customers can stay through at least 2027
connectedsolutions_legacy.transfer_option: Customers may transfer to ESS if they have approved provider

energy_storage_solutions_advantages.technology_expansion: Beyond batteries to hydrogen, thermal, mechanical, pumped hydro

regional_context.connecticut: Only New England state to fully transition to new program model
regional_context.program_origin: Massachusetts pioneered ConnectedSolutions in 2018; CT adapted and evolved

data_sources.description: Connecticut Energy Storage Solutions official site
Homeowner FAQ for Energy Storage Solutions
Connecticut PURA Energy Storage Solutions program page
Connecticut Green Bank ESS program page
FERC Order 2222 explainer on DER participation

research_methodology.approach: Comprehensive web search of utility, regulatory, program administrator, and third-party sources
research_methodology.data_integrity: HIGH - All data from official sources; no invented data
limitations: Historical ConnectedSolutions rates 2019-2022 for Connecticut not documented in available sources
Program Manual PDFs had limited extractable content
Specific C&I minimum battery size not explicitly stated
Exact dual participation rules between ESS and FCM not definitively documented
research_methodology.confidence_level: High for current ESS program; Medium for historical ConnectedSolutions CT-specific rates

critical_findings_for_bess_optimization.revenue_model: Upfront rebate + annual performance payments over 5-10 years
critical_findings_for_bess_optimization.predictable_income: Performance payments based on average kW during events, not optimization
critical_findings_for_bess_optimization.dispatch_control: Utility controls discharge via DERMS - not owner-optimized

stacking_potential.wholesale_markets: Unclear/restricted - ESS is retail DR program
stacking_potential.recommendation: Primary value is ESS + ITC; do not assume FCM stacking

critical_findings_for_bess_optimization.performance_risk: Low - automatic dispatch, no optimization required by owner
critical_findings_for_bess_optimization.technology_requirements: 70% round-trip efficiency minimum; DERMS integration mandatory
critical_findings_for_bess_optimization.program_stability: High - 9-year program through 2030; grandfathered rates through 2027
critical_findings_for_bess_optimization.behind_meter_requirement: Must be BTM; no front-of-meter eligibility

key_takeaways.program_maturity: Mature program evolved from ConnectedSolutions with significant improvements
key_takeaways.incentive_generosity: Very generous upfront incentives ($250-$600/kWh) + performance payments ($225/kW-year)
key_takeaways.accessibility_focus: Strong equity provisions for low-income and underserved communities
key_takeaways.utility_control: Utility-controlled dispatch via DERMS, not customer-optimized arbitrage
key_takeaways.market_positioning: Retail demand response program, not wholesale market participation
key_takeaways.iso_ne_context: Separate from Forward Capacity Market; unclear if dual participation allowed
key_takeaways.vpp_evolution: Moving toward VPP aggregation model (GoodLeap partnership)
key_takeaways.technology_neutral: Expanding beyond lithium-ion to hydrogen, thermal, mechanical storage
key_takeaways.program_popularity: High demand led to C&I incentive rate decreases (December 2024)
key_takeaways.contractor_ecosystem: Robust network of 40+ approved contractors and aggregators
